Vectis 36 minutes ago
It's about time the regulators and politicians realised that simply imposing endless layers of incredibly complex regulation in the interests of 'transparency' isn't going to help anything very much and is self defeating.  If the regulators are so tone deaf that they couldn't see this coming until the actual day of implementation then they are simply failing. 

Of course if a regulated firm demonstrated that lack of planning and foresight we would be subject to a 166, shamed and possibly have our careers blighted by it but the regulators and politicians can set unrealistic outcomes and unachievable deadlines and suffer no sanction at all.

Meanwhile, all those of us who have had to set aside money to comply on time with all of the MFiD 2 requirements and drive people to hit deadlines will face the question "why bother?" next time because if the regulators just move the goalposts when it suits them why should boards and shareholders take the deadlines seriously either? 

BTW Blackbag 99 is spot on. In my experience BaFin and a few other EU regulators are very flexible when it comes to domestic firms. Interestingly enough you can bet your life that if Eurex was ready and the UK exchanges weren't the UK would be getting it's backside kicked in court very quickly. Luckily if the rules don't work for Germany they are bent very quickly.

Dieselgate anyone?

In light of MiFIDII requirements, we have a responsibility to ensure our research is not used as an inducement to trade and as such it can no longer be distributed to Investment Institutions for free. Due to unbundling, our research now has a defined commercial value and therefore it is important we control the distribution of our intellectual property.

Although you do not fall under the MiFIDII regime, we have decided to continue to send you selected pieces of our research to maintain our mutual relationship, with the understanding that it will not be misused. By continuing to receive our research we will deem you to have accepted the terms attached.

PM11:08am

Hi xxxxxx

Eleesa Dadiani is the UK’s flamboyant 'Queen of Cryptocurrency', on a mission to take cryptocurrency mainstream by enabling consumers to trade it for real luxury assets.

Late last year her Mayfair fine art gallery became the first in the UK to accept payment in cryptocurrency, whilst her unique brokerage - which enables HNWs to buy luxury assets including jewels, supercars and property in cryptocurrency - facilitated the sale of four F1 cars, worth £4m, in Litecoin (a rival to Bitcoin).

She's brimming with anecdotes and colour - a descendent of Georgian nobility, expelled from six schools and breastfed as a child by gypsies, she makes a very insightful and entertaining interviewee.

Cryptocurrency and Bitcoin have garnered a reputation as a volatile get-rich-quick offering, associated with the dark web and illegal activity. Her mission is to redefine cryptocurrency and give it proper purpose - integrating it into HNW’s everyday lives, unlocking new global trade and investment routes and enabling us to buy goods with greater ease and autonomy.

Do let me know if you would like to speak to Eleesa about being a leading woman in the cryptocurrency world, making waves across traditional markets, and why cryptocurrency is about so much more than Bitcoin and getting rich.

Best,

Jacob

We would argue [...] that the more important newsflow today is not the group's performance over Christmas, but its financial guidance for FY 2018/19. This is the first time that management has provided guidance for the new financial year, and at this early stage the range of outcomes is understandably wide, with sales predicted to grow by between -2% and +4%. No profit guidance range has been given, but the company makes clear that at the mid point (ie sales growth of +1%) it would expect to deliver profits of around £705m. The current consensus average is £696m, so this is also consistent with a c1% upgrade to consensus forecasts today.

11:16 am
BE11:16am

We also think it worth noting that the company has indicated today that it intends to return c£300m to shareholders via share buybacks in FY 2018/19. Whilst Next has been returning excess capital to shareholders for many years, and the quantum indicated today is unlikely to surprise anyone much, we think the fact that the company is intending to use buybacks rather than special dividends (as it did last year) is noteworthy. The bulls will argue that this will enhance EPS by c4% and that it is a sign of management's long-term confidence in the business. The bears will argue that, without special dividends (180p per share last year), the yield comes down to less than 4% and that buying back shares in a company where profits are declining (as management guidance implies) is, in the long term, likely to be value destructive.

Customer numbers growing strongly: After re-engineering its marketing spend at the end of 2016, throughout the first nine months of 2017 Plus has been able to attract higher-value clients and do so at a lower cost. The only customer number figure released today is the annual number of new customers who have joined – at 246,000 it is 136% higher than the 2016 level and materially higher than the 96,373 ytd number reported at Q3. This suggests that Plus added c150,000 new customers in Q4 alone, in part likely due to the rapid growth in interest in the crypto-currency market

Better than expected revenue generation: This level of growth in new customers, combined with the information available at the present time, makes it quite hard to analyse the component moving parts, but we believe revenue outturn at around $425m for 2017 looks reasonable, c10% above our previous estimate of $386m. Thereafter, revenue growth will be affected by the sustainability of crypto-currency interest, the extent to which the ARPU of a crypto-currency investor differs from a non-crypto investor, in our view, and the impact of future regulation.

BE11:31am

Outlook: With the company trading so strongly in 2017, attention now turns to the rest of 2018 and regulation. ESMA updated the market on its views at the end of December, with the key conclusion being that the regulator will focus on limiting the amount of leverage that can be used with contracts for difference (CFDs) – to between 1:5 and 1:30, depending on the volatility of the underlying asset – along with areas such as margin close-out rules, negative balance protection and restrictions on marketing. We understand that there will be a short consultation period with the final implementation likely due by June 2018 at the earliest, and that all the CFD companies are now assessing the magnitude of the impact and the changes in competitor and customer behaviour that it is likely to imply. We would also pay attention to the potential for any regulatory changes affecting the crypto-currency markets and the leveraged trading of CFDs within that.

Valuation: Plus is trading on a 2017E P/E of 7.2x, a material discount to peer IG Group at 14.6x FY May 2018E. Given Plus’s improved compliance processes, growth and proven ability to quickly roll out and market new instruments, we feel this level of discount is unjustified.

BE11:35am

c30% upside potential to new Price Target of 920p, reiterate OW: IG shares have almost brushed off the initial negative share price reaction to more onerous leverage limits announced in December 2017, but we believe this still materially undervalues the company. Prior to the FCA’s proposals in December 2016, many investors would
reasonably argue that IG shares could be hit by regulation, which we believe held the rating back. Having been hit with this regulatory risk, with the shares more than halving in value from peak to trough in 2016, we find the company’s response that the new regulation would have a less than 10% effect on FY17 revenue very reassuring. Our new FY19 EPS of 46p implies the shares are now trading on a trough May-19 PE of 15.6x, with a dividend yield of 5%. In a market where ‘winners’ seem disproportionately rewarded with a high valuation multiple, this rating seems anomalous for a global leader in CFD trading. Accordingly, we raise our PT by 42% to 920p, using our ‘pre regulation’ PE of 20x on FY19E, offering compelling upside potential of 28%.

Tom Dalgleish Sign of the times that we're contemplating dealers and CFD's as an adjunct a notional currency
BE11:35am

What’s the right rating in a post-regulation market? We believe a key debate is whether IG should trade on a higher or lower multiple ‘post regulation’ vs ‘pre regulation’. If the key investment case risk of regulation creates ‘only’ a 10% reduction in FY19 EPS vs FY18, and if there are no further regulatory shocks, then the argument for a higher multiple seems strong. Much will depend on industry dynamics from here. Will IG take market share from weaker competitors now we have a level playing field from a leverage perspective, or will some competitors move offshore and thrive as they evade new regulation? We raise FY18 EPS by 23% and FY19 by 15%, reflecting no effect from regulation in FY18 before a 7% revenue reduction in FY19. We assume a 70% drop through of revenue foregone, creating a 10% hit to FY19 EPS vs FY18

11:35 am
BE11:36am

Upside and downside case: range still substantial, but narrowed. Our upside case assumes no fall in EPS as regulation has a limited impact on client activity. Using a PE rating of 23x on FY18E this offers c64% upside potential to our upside case of 1175p. Our downside case uses our previous more cautious assumptions from regulation in the UK and EU (in line with our previous base case), and a regulatory hit in Asia. Using a PE of 12.5x on our downside case EPS drives a fair value of 475p, 35% downside risk.

BE11:36am

This is a good sign the company is on track for our $385 million 4Q17 AOR (adjusted operating revenue) estimate and above the low end of HAWK’s lowered 4Q17 $371 to $412 million AOR guidance.
 We note that our HAWK 4Q17E US Retail volume Y/Y 2 year growth stack assumes a deceleration by 340bp to -1.4% from 3Q’s +2%. A 4Q17 2 year stack of 2% would lift our ~5% volume Y/Y growth estimate to 8.4% in 4Q17 and contribute an additional $6 million total AOR.
We Believe 2018 Guidance Will Be Below The Consensus. Street 2018 AOR estimate implies 14%-19% growth. With Cash Star partially offset by Kroger we estimate nearly 7% organic growth, which we expect should be on the conservative side for our expectation of a high single digits organic guide.
